description: From Middle English rakyl (“chain”), apparently related to Old Frisian rakels (“chain”), French racle ("the iron ring of a door") (from a Germanic source), and also Middle English rakente, from Old English racente (“chain, fetter”). More at rackan.

entries.meaning: (countable, UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) A chain.
(uncountable, UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) Noisy talk.

verbs.description: rackle (third-person singular simple present rackles, present participle rackling, simple past and past participle rackled)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) To talk noisily; rattle on.

description: Uncertain. Probably from rack (“to drive; move; go forward rapidly”), alteration of Middle English reken (“to drive; move; tend”), from Old Norse reka, vreka (“to drive; drift; toss”)  +‎ -le (“tending or prone to”). Related to Icelandic reka, Swedish vräka, Danish vrage, English wrack.

adjectives.description: rackle (comparative more rackle, superlative most rackle)

entries.meaning: Of a person: rash, impetuous, reckless
